awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of multiplexed Brillouin microscopy which introduces a new microscopy modality with a contrast that is desirable, but currently unavailable. This type of microscopy has applications in ophthalmology for refractive surgery, where current screening for at-risk patients is based on late-onset morphological metrics. Beyond the primary application in ophthalmology, the technology could offer a non-invasive approach to extracting information about morphology and chemical pathways, not mechanical properties. Mechanical information requires perturbation, often destruction, of the sample, which affects the quality of required information.  Widely available Brillouin instruments could help address this gap. 

This I-Corps project is focused on the development of Brillouin microscopy based on spectral analysis of light scattered from a sample, which allows production of high-resolution, three-dimensional maps of the longitudinal elastic modulus of materials. Brillouin spectroscopy has been widely used for material testing and environmental sensing. In the past two decades, a new type of spectrometer has improved the speed of acquisition to enable biological applications. The Brillouin technology developed in this project can be further sped up by multiplexing the readout to many points simultaneously. This multiplexed Brillouin microscopy expands the types of potential applications of the technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project explored the commercialization of novel Brillouin microscopy for applications in ophthalmology. Brillouin microscopy is based on spectral analysis of light scattered from a sample, which  allows producing high resolution 3D maps of the stiffness of materials; as a result, it can probe how stiff/soft materials are without any physical contact, thus making it  particularly useful for the characterization of fragile/biological materials. Surgical correction of myopia and keratoconus identification/management are separate but interrelated issues of major significance. Myopia impacts ~1.4 billion people worldwide, with prevalence expected to double, affecting more than 50% of the US population, by 2050. The primary goal of screening protocols for laser vision correction (LVC) is the identification of patients with subclinical keratoconus, where refractive surgery can trigger the development of ectasia. Currently, less than 10% of eligible patients undergo LVC, with most citing safety concerns as the major factor.  Refractive surgery screening remains inherently conservative, as only morphological evaluations are currently available in the clinic; thus, many otherwise reasonable candidates are excluded from surgery.  Yet, numerous cases of postoperative ectasia continue to occur despite the utilization of multiple screening strategies. In this grant we studied the market segment of refractive surgeon to explore the product market fit of Brillouin instruments. We concluded there is product market fit, however pricing of the instrument needs to be lowered.
